columns.text: In this exercise, we will calculate how much interest we own in our credit cards from Shady Banks Savings and Loan for the first year. Suppose the commencing interest rate for the first six months is 1.12% compounded monthly, increasing to 17.8% also compounded monthly. In that case, we will determine the interest expense for the first year if we have an $8,000 balance transfer from the previous account and with no subsequent payments made.
First, to determine the interest expense for the year, having two different interests used, we will calculate the future value of the $8,000 payment for the first six months.

The future value is the value of a cash flow at a future date. The future value considers the present value of the cash flow multiplied by the factor of the rate and period. The computation of future value can be expressed with the following equation:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Future value} &= PV\times(1 + i)^t\
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which represent the present value\
$i$, which refers to the discount rate \
$t$, which symbolizes the period

In determining the future value we will consider the following details from the problem:

| Particulars                              |         |
|------------------------------------------|---------|
| Interst rate (first six months)          | 1.25%   |
| Interest rate (after six months onwards) | 17.80%  |
| Present value                            | $8,000  |
The period we will use to calculate the future value for the first six months is six, the number of times the interest compound for the 1.25% rate.
Next, we will consider the future value for the first six months as the present value and calculate the future value for the next six months using the 17.80% interest rate.

Let's now calculate the interest expense for the yeaar
$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Interest expense} &=\$8,793.69-\$8,000
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$793.69 }
\end{aligned}$$

**Based, on our calculation the interest expense due for the first year to Shady Banks Savings and Loan is $793.69.**

In summary, since there are no prior payments made, the interest expense is the difference between the future value of the payment balance and the existing balance. We determined the future value of the balance by considering both the respective interest rates and the compounding periods.
